Dear Lauren Skinner:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & R 400.4158 Intervention standards and prohibitions.
Section Rule 158. (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow
Description written policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(iv) Verbal abuse including the use of derogatory or discriminatory
language including negative references to a youth’s background
or appearance or mental state. Yelling, threats, ridicule, or
humiliation are strictly prohibited.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth A resides at Wolverine Shelter. Staff 1 is a staff at
Wolverine. A few months ago, Youth A was in the process of
going AWOL. Staff 1 told Youth A he could "beat Youth A's ass"
because there were no cameras. Staff 1 told Youth A "that is why
another client fucked you". Youth A denied knowing what Staff 1
was referring to.
Investigation Foster Care Worker 1 was interviewed via phone on
3/14/2025. She reported having no further information about the
incident. She also reported learning about the allegations from a
report in MiSACWIS. She reported Youth A never told her about
the allegations or any issues with Staff 1.
Complainant was interviewed via phone on 3/14/2025. She
reported learning about the allegations during another
investigation in which Youth A was interviewed as a possible
witness. She also reported Youth A reported not liking Staff 1.
Clinical Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility
on 3/17/2025. She reported having no knowledge of the
allegations and that Staff 1 works second shift at the facility. She
also reported Youth A and Youth B were in school but will be
brought to the facility for interviews.
Youth A was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/17/2025. Youth A reported a couple of months ago, Youth A and
Youth H were going AWOL when Staff 1 and Staff 2 began to
follow Youth A and Youth H. Youth A reported staff are not
supposed to follow youth going AWOL past the fence on the
property. This fence ends at the stop sign at the end of the block.
Youth A reported Staff 1 and Staff 2 continued to follow Youth A
and Youth H until the next stop sign where Staff 1 is reported to
2

have made the comment “that is why another client fucked you”
and “I know I can beat your ass because there are no cameras
around here”. Youth A reported not liking Staff 1, but that Staff 1
has been nice since the incident and Youth A feels safe at the
facility.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/17/2025. Staff 1 denied the allegations of speaking
inappropriately to Youth A during the situation in which Youth A
was going AWOL. He also reported staff are not to follow any
youth going AWOL past the stop sign (end of fence) at the corner.
He reported writing an incident report about the situation and
described the AWOL process as having to wait 15-minutes before
writing a Law Enforcement report. Staff 1 also reported never
speaking to a youth in a negative or inappropriate way.
Staff 1 was interviewed again face-to-face at the facility on
3/20/2025. Staff 1 now reported following Youth A and Youth H
past the first stop sign but stopping near the church on the next
block. Staff 1 continued to deny saying anything inappropriate to
Youth A but only told Youth A and Youth H to return to the facility.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/17/2025. He reported being present during the AWOL by Youth
A and Youth H. He reported both he and Staff 1 stopped at the
end of the fence that is next to the first stop sign because staff are
not to follow youth any longer from that point. He reported never
hearing Staff 1 speak to youth in an inappropriate manner and
Staff 1 only encouraged Youth A and Youth B not to go AWOL. He
reported Staff 1 is a liked staff who tends to be silly at times and
will joke with the youth who seem to like Staff 1. Staff 2 was
interviewed again face-to-face at the facility on 3/20/2025. He
reported he may have been thinking of another AWOL when
interviewed a couple of days ago. He now reported going past the
stop sign on to the next block near the church. Staff 2 still denied
Staff 1 said anything inappropriate to either Youth A or Youth H.
He also reported Youth A and Youth H got into an argument and
had a lot of miscommunications between the two youth (Youth A
and Youth H). Staff 2 reported Staff 1 has no history of
inappropriately speaking with youth and goes above and beyond
in helping youth in the program.
Administrator was interviewed via phone on 3/17/2025. She
reported not being aware of the allegations but will provide any
needed information.
3

Youth H was interviewed face-to-face at his current
placement on 3/19/2025. Youth H reported going AWOL with
Youth A that is outlined in the allegations. Youth H reported Youth
A was trying to pick a fight with Staff 1 while Staff 1 was trying to
convince Youth A and Youth H to return to the facility. Youth H
reported Staff 1 (never able to identify Staff 1’s name but gave a
physical description of Staff 1 that matched Staff 1) did say Youth
A’s sister “F” Youth A and Youth A responded with a threat to beat
up Staff 1. Youth H also reported Staff 1 then said Staff 1 would
beat up Youth A. Youth H reported not liking any of the staff at the
facility.
Staff 7 was interviewed via phone on 3/25/2025. He reported
writing the incident report dated 11/25/24 and gave a similar
description of the incident as written. He also reported being the
single staff and the youth were Youth A and Youth H. He reported
overhearing a staff swear once or twice but was unable to provide
any specifics (when, where, and who). He also reported the
swearing was not in a threatening manner towards the youth.
Documents Reviewed:
Wolverine Human Services Critical Incident Report for Youth
A dated 11/21/24. This document outlines the incident as Youth A
going AWOL at 4:55 pm and was written by Staff 2. Failed
interventions are documented as staff giving verbal directive. Staff
are documented as staying close to Youth A until Youth A reached
a specific street. There is no documentation about Youth H being
present.
Incident Report MDHHS for Wolverine Human Services dated
11/22/24. This document reads the same as the “Critical Incident
Report”. Staff 1 and Staff 2 are identified as the staff involved.
There is no documentation about Youth H being present.
Wolverine Human Services Critical Incident Report for Youth
A dated 11/23/24. This document outlines the incident as Youth A
and Youth H going AWOL at 4:55 pm and was written by Staff 7. It
is documented Youth A and Youth H walked out of the gym once
the door was opened and left the grounds of the facility. Staff 7 is
documented as asking them (Youth A and Youth H) to return but
continued to walk away. Once Youth A and Youth H crossed a
main street, Staff 7 returned to the facility and began the AWOL
protocol. The staff documented as being involved is Staff 7 only.
4

Incident Report MDHHS for Wolverine Human Services dated
11/25/24. This document outlines the incident of AWOL on
11/24/24 as described in the Wolverine Critical Incident report.
The staff documented as being involved is Staff 7 only.
Wolverine Human Services Truancy Policy and Procedure
BSM-2 RTX dated 3/1/24. This document outlines that staff are to
make efforts to verbally redirect the truanting youth and offer the
youth support and alternatives to truancy. Staff are not to
physically intervene on the WHS property other than in
accordance with CPI protocol. Staff are to walk with the youth
while continuing to provide verbal support and redirection
encouraging the youth not to truant. Staff are to complete an
incident reported which is to detail the events leading to the
truancy, time of truancy, and time Law Enforcement was notified.
Wolverine Human Services Communication with recipients of
care (youth) policy dated 3/27/24. This document outlines that
all staff are to communicate with youth in a professional manner.
Staff are not to swear at, threaten, or communicate in any way
that would violate Child Protection Law. Communication not
allowed includes, sexual, predatory, and/or illegal. Staff are also to
report any staff that violates this policy.
Wolverine Human Services Line of sight policy dated 3/27/24.
This document outlines staff’s duty when providing line of sight
supervision with youth. Line of sight is described as having the
ability to reasonably visually distinguish and recognize individuals.
During all events staff are to remain in ratio and maintain line of
sight when in direct supervision of the youth.
Wolverine Human Services 17. Employee Standards of
Conduct dated 10.24. This document outlines staff’s expected
behaviors. Staff are not to sleep while working and staff’s primary
responsibility is the appropriate supervision of line of sight of all
youth in their care.
HR record for Staff 1 was reviewed. Staff 1 was hired on
9/9/2024. There were 4-documented disciplinary actions
documented in his personnel file. The following are the 4-
disciplanary actions, reason for action, and corrective actions to
be taken.
• Action Taken: Written warning dated 10/24/24. Reason for
Action: Erratic Work Behavior, violation of company rules,
violation of safety rules, and unsatisfactory work
performance. Staff 1 engaged in cursing, arguing, and
5

degrading another staff member in front of youth Staff 1
was responsible for maintaining line of sight of. Corrective
Action to be taken involve Staff 1 following WHS policies,
procedures, and protocols always. This document was
signed by Staff 1 on 10/28/24.
• Action Taken: Written warning and 3-days suspension
(3/10/25, 3/13/25, and 3/14/25. Reason for Action:
insubordination and violation of company rules dated
3/6/25. Staff 1 became upset when his assignment was
switched and he used his personal cell phone while
working and after receiving a directive to put the phone
away, Staff 1 continued to text on the phone before putting
the phone away. Corrective Action to be taken: Any further
instance will result in further disciplinary action. This
document was signed by Staff 1 on 3/16/25.
• There is no documentation of action taken. Reason for
Action: Insubordination dated 3/9/25. Staff 1 was sitting in
his car at 3:08 pm leaving staff and youth out of ratio.
Corrective Action to be taken: Any further instance will
result in further disciplinary action. This document was
signed by Staff 1 on 3/16/25.
• Action Taken: Warning dated 2/25/25. Reason for Action:
unsatisfactory work performance. Staff 1 asked for an
assignment (youth) switch. When the assignment was
switched, Staff 1 didn't want to work with the new
assignment (youth) and continued with his original
assignment (youth). Corrective Action to be taken: Any
further instance will result in further disciplinary action. This
document was signed by Staff 1 on 2/25/25.
Documentation indicates Staff 1 is current on all required
trainings.
Walk-through:
A walk-through of the facility occurred with a focus on the
bedrooms of Youth A and Youth B. Both rooms were clean and
appropriately furnished. Overall, the facility is an older 3 story
structure and is fairly maintained.
6

Analysis Regarding the allegation of Staff 1 speaking to Youth A in an
inappropriate manner, there is not enough evidence to support
this allegation as based on interviews of staff and youth.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
Technical assistance was offered regarding the written
documentation (Incident Reports) of youth going AWOL. Both
Staff 1 and Staff 2 reported Youth A and Youth H going AWOL
which is outlined in the allegations, but an incident report with
Staff 1, Staff 2, Youth A and Youth H involved was never
discovered. This leads to the possibility of two different
conclusions. First the possibility that an incident report may not
have been written. Second since the reported incident took place
four months prior to this investigation, those interviewed may not
be reporting the actual details that occurred in the allegations
(Staff 2 reported in his second interview that he reported on the
wrong incident during the first interview). The reason for this
Technical Assistance is a focus on the facility developing a system
to ensure accurate documentation occurred in a timely manner.
The second part of this Technical Assistance is the development
of a daily over-site review to ensure all required documentation
was completed.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It was reported Staff 1 will sleep while at work often and that he
will sit in his chair and fall asleep.
Investigation Complainant was interviewed via phone on 3/14/2025. She
reported learning about the allegations during another
investigation in which Youth B was interviewed as a possible
witness. She also reported Youth B reported not liking Staff 1 after
telling Complainant about Staff 1 sleeping while working.
7

Clinical Supervisor was interviewed face-to-face at the facility
on 3/17/2025. She reported having no knowledge of the
allegations and that Staff 1 works second shift at the facility.
Youth B was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/17/2025. Youth B reported observing Staff 1 sleeping
everywhere in the facility while working. Youth B also reported not
being certain about the time of day or where Staff 1 was sleeping
but stated, “Staff 1 just goes to sleep”. Youth A reported Staff 1 fell
asleep during an outing at a movie yesterday and Youth B knew
Staff 1 was sleeping because Staff 1 was “snoring really loud”.
Youth B reported Youth C, Youth D, Youth E, Youth F, and Youth
G were present at the movie. Youth B also reported a lot of the
staff sleep on the job but was unable to remember the names of
the staff or when they were sleeping. Youth B reported not liking
Staff 1 but feeling safe at the facility.
Staff 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/17/2025. Staff 1 also denied sleeping on the job, but did suggest
he may have dozed off during the movie but is not fully aware if he
did or not. He also reported Staff 3 was present in the van ride
and Staff 1 reported believing he may have dozed off during the
van ride for a moment. Staff 1 was interviewed again face-to-
face at the facility on 3/20/2025. He again reported he didn’t
sleep during the movie but “did doze off”. He also reported
knowing everything about the movie to suggest he was aware of
what was occurring around him. He reported Youth C was his
one-on-one youth and sat next to Staff 1 throughout the movie.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/17/2025. Youth C reported witnessing staff sleeping but was
unable to recall the names of the staff or where this occurred.
Youth C also reported Staff 1 fell asleep at the movies, but the
movie woke Staff 1 up. Youth C reported never witnessing Staff 1
fall asleep on the job and when sleeping at the movies it was for a
very short time before Staff 1 woke up. Youth C also reported
liking Staff 1 and feeling safe at the facility.
Youth D was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/17/2025. Youth D reported going to the movies with Staff 1, Staff
3, Youth A, Youth C, Youth E, Youth F, and Youth G yesterday.
Youth D denied Staff 1 fell asleep and described Staff 1 as a good
staff who is helpful. Youth D also reported feeling safe at the
facility.
8

Youth E was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/17/2025. Youth E reported being at the movies but never
observing Staff 1 sleeping. He reported not sitting near Staff 1
during the movie. Youth F reported not witnessing any staff
sleeping at the movies nor at the facility. Youth F also reported
Staff 1 is a “good” staff who is active with the youth.
Youth F was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/17/2025. Youth F reported being at the movies and never
witnessing Staff 1 nor other staff sleeping during the movie. Youth
F also reported never witnessing staff sleeping at the facility.
Youth F described Staff 1 as a good staff who is “really nice”.
Youth G was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/17/2025. Youth G reported attending the movies that occurred
during the allegations. Youth G reported Staff 1, nor any other
staff were sleeping during the movie. Youth G reported never
observing any staff sleeping at the facility and described Staff 1 as
a “good, nice staff who is fun to be around”.
Administrator was interviewed via phone on 3/17/2025. She
reported not being aware of the allegations but will provide any
needed information.
Staff 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
3/20/2025. He reported being part of the group of youth and staff
who attending the movie where the allegation reports Staff 1 was
sleeping. He also reported Staff 1 was sitting in front of the rest of
the group and didn’t see or hear Staff 1 sleeping. He reported
working with Staff 1 and never observing Staff 1 sleeping nor
nesting. He also reported Staff 1 is a “good staff” who spends a lot
of time with the youth and is always involved in different activities
with the youth.
Staff 3 was interviewed via phone on 3/20/2025. He reported
being present at the movies but never observed Staff 1 sleeping.
He also reported Staff 1 and Youth C were sitting closer to the
screen than Staff 3.
Staff 4 was interviewed via phone on 3/20/2025. She reported
being present at the movies and having her own one-on-one youth
she was supervising. She also reported never witnessing Staff 1
sleep but was a couple of rows behind Staff 1 and Youth C and
would not have had a clear view of Staff 1 and Youth C.
9

Staff 5 was interviewed via phone on 3/20/2025. She reported
being present at the movies but had no knowledge of Staff 1 or
anyone else sleeping. She also reported not being able to see
others (Staff and youth) and had her own one-on-one youth to
supervise.
Staff 7 was interviewed via phone on 3/25/2025. He denied
observing Staff 1 or any other staff sleeping during their shifts.
Documents Reviewed:
Wolverine Human Services 17. Employee Standards of
Conduct dated 10.24. This document outlines staff’s expected
behaviors. Staff are not to sleep while working and staff’s primary
responsibility is the appropriate supervision of line of sight of all
youth in their care.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as evidenced by interviews
with staff and youth. Staff 1 admitted to “dozing off” and Youth C
reported witnessing Staff 1 sleep during the movie outing. The
facility’s policy states staff are not to sleep while working. There is
no evidence to support that Staff 1 was sleeping at the facility.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
